Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of man in grotesque style. Head only. Mould-made. White coating with black paint around eyes. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Grotesque style cult attendants like this were made from the Early Hellenistic to the first century AD. Possibly the same mould as NA613 also in Cambridge MCA. Similar in style to 1st century BC – 1st century AD Egyptian parallel (Török 1995 Pl.118, no.220), but could be earlier. Török, L. 1995. ‘Hellenistic and Roman terracottas from Egypt’. Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.539) (Phase 1)
